Washington National Cathedral will host a magical program of Russian music on May 15 at 4:00 pm.

Progressive dinner for Hyde-Addison May 14

People in Georgetown are talking about the Progressive Dinner. At the Patron's party for the Georgetown House tour last week, a fellow guest insisted I tell an assembled group all about it and how it works. I was handed business cards with requests for an invitation.

He's all right! Aren't you, cat? Poor cat! Poor slob! Poor slob without a name! The way I see it I haven't got the right to give him one. We don't belong to each other. We just took up one day by the river. I don't want to own anything until I find a place where me and things go together.

The Georgetown Chapter of Business Networking International (BNI) invites you May 10 for a mixer at the Daily Grill at 1310 Wisconsin Avenue from 5:00 -7:00 pm.

A Love Letter for my Mother

As we all know, Mothers’ Day is Sunday. An important day despite those who chalk it up to a Hallmark fabrication. What could be more valuable than honoring the woman who brought you into the world? For me, that woman is Bonnie Dickinson Huntley. AKA, Bonnie Lou.

Life happens

“Life happens to you while you’re busy making other plans.”

Found: Affordable escape to New York. Vamoose!

Georgetown to New York in four-and-a-half hours. Direct.

Skip the train, downtown traffic, the shuttle delays. Point to point.

Welcome to the new hip way to get to the City from it's tiny cousin to the south. (That's right: Georgetown, the mini-Manhattan.)

Social Safeway celebrates first year in Georgetown with LEED Certification

Georgetown’s “Social” Safeway celebrates its first anniversary during the week of May 2 with a host of events and activities, highlighted by a LEED Certification Announcement on Friday, May 6 starting at 10:00 am.

Tudor Place hosts annual garden party

Despite cool evening temperatures, the Nineteenth Annual Garden Party at Tudor Place was teeming with residents and guests eager to take in the live music, gourmet buffet, lush green lawn, and colonial history.

Wednesday night, National’s Stadium was awash with wide-eyed kids and anxious adults all eagerly waiting to take their turn at bat atop the verdant National’s baseball field.

Here comes the sun—Protect your skin

The month of May is Skin Cancer Awareness month. Why is this important? With the warm weather now upon us and the sun gaining strength every day, it is vital to be cognizant of protecting your skin from the effects of the sun.

By Carol Buckley

Current Staff Writer

For some Georgetowners, the ongoing construction on O and P streets is raising more than old streetcar tracks. The work has also heightened concerns over the placement of large utility meters on the fronts of historic homes.

Home to politicians on The Georgetown House Tour April 30

The house at 3018 Dumbarton Street was built around 1888 by George Green, a water registrar for the City of Georgetown, for his large family, and it has been the home to a number of famous politicians over the years.

Susan Calloway fine art paintings on sale at the French Market

Visit Susan Calloway Fine Arts during the 8th Annual Georgetown French Market on April 29thand 30th. You’ll find a luscious selection of nineteenth and twentieth century European and American landscapes, cityscapes, still life, and seascapes at up to 50% off.

Felicia Stidham, writer and real estate broker, R.I.P.

Felicia Stidham, a writer, historian and real estate broker, died suddenly last week at the age of 64. A memorial service will take place Monday, May 2 at 12 noon at St. John's Episcopal Church in Georgetown.
